data.message: they want to make us dummy coders
They want to make your life easier. You're responsible for what you put in your project
sure Mohammad Tayseer , but it is like a spoon feeding ,this will decrease the possibilities to Google the problem so decrease beginners knowledge.

Mohamed Sameeh Sharaf if we proceed with that logic then we should all do assembly. The .net platform spoon feeds you, your IDE does too. Now if I ask you how to do a custom component in .net or manually build a project and you don't know how or got stuck in linking then that's on you not on the technology, a convenient technology doesn't produce bad developers.

لا دا مش قصدى 
انا قصدى انا مثلا فى البداية - ومازلت - كنت لما ببقى عاوز اعمل دون لود لفايل او اعمل اى وظيفة فى البرنامج كنت بقول how to download file in using C# كنت بدور على النت وعلشان مكنتش بعرف اعمل سيرش كويس كنت بتوه وبخش من لينكات للينكات وبستفاد وبقرا عن مميزات جديدة فى اللغة و وبعرف بلوجات مفيده بتابعها وبعرف طرق جديدة وطرق افضل وافضل 

لكن مع ال code snippet search الوضع هيختلف .

I understand your sentiment and in all fairness I can't argue that this _will never_ happen. Our industry has a history of insinuating laziness and the lack of mastery by the magnitude of tools at a developer's disposal.
It's for instance, not uncommon for a Java developer to know more about the innards of her platform than a .Net developer.

Why? Because of the tooling given to a Java developer, at what stage is it given and how does the community feel about it. 
The grand majority of Java developers for example learn to construct GUIs by hand before they move to a GUI builder. That isn't the case with .Net, same for packaging a project, as two naive examples but common amongst beginners.

People with a long history of imperative programming knowledge and dynamic typing face problems when moving to a more rigid line of thoughts like functional programming and different typing systems. A common luxury not present in FP is variable mutability, non-recursive iteration structures.

But you also can't argue that it isn't entirely the developer's responsibility and technology -although a contributing factor- isn't the sole offender here. It's all _on you_
